articles.headline: Uptick in Vasectomies Seen as Sign of Recession
articles.snippet: Anecdotal evidence supports the intuition that more people might hesitate to expand their families during a downturn.
articles.abstract: Anecdotal evidence supports the intuition that more people might hesitate to expand their families during a downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last November I learned, to my great surprise, that I was pregnant. At age 47, I was not exactly trying to conceive.

articles.headline: Austere Times? Perfect
articles.snippet: Thrift is re-emerging as a desirable consumer value, and devoted penny-pinchers are having the time of their lives.
articles.abstract: Thrift is re-emerging as a desirable consumer value, and devoted penny-pinchers are having the time of their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Millions of Americans have trimmed expenses because they have had their jobs or hours cut, or fear they will. But a subset of savers are reducing costs not just with purpose, but with relish. These are the gleefully frugal.

articles.headline: Personal Bankruptcy for Madoff More Likely
articles.snippet: A judge rejected arguments from the government and a trustee that forcing Bernard L. Madoff into personal bankruptcy would be unnecessarily expensive.
articles.abstract: A judge rejected arguments from the government and a trustee that forcing Bernard L. Madoff into personal bankruptcy would be unnecessarily expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the objections of the government, a federal judge cleared the way on Friday for Bernard L. Madoff to be forced into personal bankruptcy, a ruling that could help those who invested with one of the many big hedge funds that lost money in his vast Ponzi scheme.

articles.headline: Navigating a Tax Return Minefield
articles.snippet: When given a chance, many people still seem to forget to tell the I.R.S. about some of their undocumented income.
articles.abstract: When given a chance, many people still seem to forget to tell the I.R.S. about some of their undocumented income.
articles.lead_paragraph: With just a few more days to file your tax returns, you may be tempted  especially in this down economy  to shave a little income, maybe, or add a little more to your deductions.

articles.headline: Skype Founders May Seek to Buy It Back
articles.snippet: The founders of Skype are said to have approached several private equity firms to make a bid for the Internet calling service.
articles.abstract: The founders of Skype are said to have approached several private equity firms to make a bid for the Internet calling service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The European duo who created Skype and sold it to eBay for billions may have another trick up their sleeve: buying it back.

articles.headline: Cities Turn to Fees to Fill Budget Gaps
articles.snippet: With budgets under strain, municipalities are imposing or raising a host of fees to raise revenue; some charge for things like responding to auto accidents.
articles.abstract: With budgets under strain, municipalities are imposing or raising a host of fees to raise revenue; some charge for things like responding to auto accidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: After her sport utility vehicle sideswiped a van in early February, Shirley Kimel was amazed at how quickly a handful of police officers and firefighters in Winter Haven, Fla., showed up. But a real shock came a week later, when a letter arrived from the city billing her $316 for the cost of responding to the accident.

articles.headline: Graft in China Covers Up Toll of Coal Mines
articles.snippet: Disasters in Chinese coal mines are often covered up and death tolls underreported as businessmen and officials make common cause and profit.
articles.abstract: Disasters in Chinese coal mines are often covered up and death tolls underreported as businessmen and officials make common cause and profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHONGLOU, China  When an underground fire killed 35 men at the bottom of a coal shaft last year, the telltale signs of another Chinese mining disaster were everywhere: Black smoke billowed into the sky, dozens of rescuers searched nine hours for survivors, and sobbing relatives besieged the mine’s iron gate.

articles.headline: Showdown Seen Between Banks and Regulators
articles.snippet: Industry executives are bracing for fights with the government over repayment of bailout money and forced sales of bad mortgages.
articles.abstract: Industry executives are bracing for fights with the government over repayment of bailout money and forced sales of bad mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration completes its examinations of the nation’s largest banks, industry executives are bracing for fights with the government over repayment of bailout money and forced sales of bad mortgages.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: Washington Churches Eye the Obamas
articles.snippet: The president is considering black and multiracial churches that are not the biggest or best known.
articles.abstract: The president is considering black and multiracial churches that are not the biggest or best known.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The invitations have come in neatly typed letters, whispered entreaties and please-join-us blogs. They have come from predominantly white churches and predominantly black churches, venerable churches with distinguished lineages and smaller, plucky churches with little more than spirit and gumption.

articles.headline: Telenor Ruling Stirs Fear of Court Shopping in Russia
articles.snippet: Malleable courts and widespread jurisdiction shopping prevent Western creditors from collecting debts in Russia.
articles.abstract: Malleable courts and widespread jurisdiction shopping prevent Western creditors from collecting debts in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: OMSK, Russia  This Siberian city would seem an unlikely place to decide the most prominent civil lawsuit in Russia today.

articles.headline: States Slashing Social Programs for Vulnerable
articles.snippet: A large majority of states are slicing into social safety nets, often crippling preventive efforts that officials say would save money over time.
articles.abstract: A large majority of states are slicing into social safety nets, often crippling preventive efforts that officials say would save money over time.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  Battered by the recession and the deepest and most widespread budget deficits in several decades, a large majority of states are slicing into their social safety nets  often crippling preventive efforts that officials say would save money over time.

articles.headline: Tech Recruiting Clashes With Immigration Rules
articles.snippet: Technology executives say restrictive visa and immigration limits have imperiled their ability to hire more of the world’s best engineers.
articles.abstract: Technology executives say restrictive visa and immigration limits have imperiled their ability to hire more of the world’s best engineers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Where’s Sanjay?

articles.headline: Recession Pain, Even in Palm Beach
articles.snippet: The downturn, combined with the Bernie Madoff fraud, has reduced wealth in Palm Beach, Fla., adding to below-the-surface tensions in the town.
articles.abstract: The downturn, combined with the Bernie Madoff fraud, has reduced wealth in Palm Beach, Fla., adding to below-the-surface tensions in the town.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla.

articles.headline: He Doesn’t Let Money Managers Off the Hook
articles.snippet: John C. Bogle, the founder of Vanguard, says many institutional investors have failed to advocate on behalf of shareholders.
articles.abstract: John C. Bogle, the founder of Vanguard, says many institutional investors have failed to advocate on behalf of shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERY once in a while, if only for sanity’s sake, it is wise to leave our bankrupt era behind and seek out a bit of wisdom from a moral authority. It’s a challenging exercise, given that so many formerly stellar reputations are now shipwrecked and that all those once-smart guys and gals have been reduced to bull-market geniuses.

articles.headline: So Botox Isn’t Just Skin Deep
articles.snippet: Botox has become a wrinkle-removal gold mine for the drug maker Allergan, but some doctors are also now using it to treat ailments like migraines and oily skin.
articles.abstract: Botox has become a wrinkle-removal gold mine for the drug maker Allergan, but some doctors are also now using it to treat ailments like migraines and oily skin.
articles.lead_paragraph: DR. MARK STILLMAN, the director of the Center for Headache and Pain at the Cleveland Clinic, has a treatment for people with frequent migraines: he injects Botox around the head and neck.

articles.headline: A New Chapter of Grief in Plath-Hughes Legacy
articles.snippet: The news of the suicide of Sylvia Plath’s son, Nicholas Hughes, has cut through two distant and disconnected worlds in vastly different ways.
articles.abstract: The news of the suicide of Sylvia Plath’s son, Nicholas Hughes, has cut through two distant and disconnected worlds in vastly different ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  Before his death in 1998, the English poet Ted Hughes published a searing volume about his life with Sylvia Plath called “Birthday Letters.” The poems, almost all addressed to Ms. Plath, explored the beauty and then fracturing of their marriage before her suicide in 1963.

articles.headline: Crisis Altering Wall St. As Stars Begin to Scatter
articles.snippet: With banks facing federal limits after the bailouts, veterans are joining start-ups and foreign companies.
articles.abstract: With banks facing federal limits after the bailouts, veterans are joining start-ups and foreign companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The turning point for Stephan Jung came in February, around the time bonus checks were slashed. A veteran of UBS, one of many banks tarnished by the financial crisis, Mr. Jung realized that the old Wall Street would not be bouncing back any time soon. It was time to head for the new.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Louise Story

articles.headline: China Slows Purchases of U.S. and Other Bonds
articles.snippet: Reversing its role as the world’s fastest-growing buyer of U.S. Treasuries and other foreign bonds, the Chinese government sold bonds heavily this winter.
articles.abstract: Reversing its role as the world’s fastest-growing buyer of U.S. Treasuries and other foreign bonds, the Chinese government sold bonds heavily this winter.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Reversing its role as the world’s fastest-growing buyer of United States Treasuries and other foreign bonds, the Chinese government actually sold bonds heavily in January and February before resuming purchases in March, according to data released during the weekend by China’s central bank.

articles.headline: In Rescue of Captain, Navy Kills 3 Pirates
articles.snippet: President Obama had authorized the use of force if Capt. Richard Phillips was believed to be in danger, so U.S. snipers fired when the pirates aimed an automatic rifle at their hostage.
articles.abstract: President Obama had authorized the use of force if Capt. Richard Phillips was believed to be in danger, so U.S. snipers fired when the pirates aimed an automatic rifle at their hostage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Navy Seal snipers rescued an American cargo ship captain unharmed and killed three Somali pirates in a daring operation in the Indian Ocean on Sunday, ending a five-day standoff between United States naval forces and a small band of brigands in a covered orange lifeboat off the Horn of Africa.
articles.byline: By Robert D. McFadden and Scott Shane

articles.headline: In Afghanistan, Soldiers Bridge 2 Stages of War
articles.snippet: The war stands to become more hopeful, but perhaps more bloody, as U.S. units push into Taliban sanctuaries.
articles.abstract: The war stands to become more hopeful, but perhaps more bloody, as U.S. units push into Taliban sanctuaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: DANGALEEK, Afghanistan — First Lt. C. Carter Cheek stood in the Afghan rain. His patrol had climbed a switchback road leading to the Taliban-dominated village of Wanat, the location of the bloodiest battle for American forces in Afghanistan since 2005.

articles.headline: ‘Hyperlocal’ Web Sites Deliver News Without Newspapers
articles.snippet: Just as some cities’ newspapers sputter, a handful of Web sites emerge to cull local content from government data, blogs and news media.
articles.abstract: Just as some cities’ newspapers sputter, a handful of Web sites emerge to cull local content from government data, blogs and news media.
articles.lead_paragraph: If your local newspaper shuts down, what will take the place of its coverage? Perhaps a package of information about your neighborhood, or even your block, assembled by a computer.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Papers Try to Get Out of a Box
articles.snippet: Newspapers are increasingly talking about putting up pay walls and tracking the use of content online.
articles.abstract: Newspapers are increasingly talking about putting up pay walls and tracking the use of content online.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much is this sentence worth? This paragraph? This column? Would copying and replicating it elsewhere enhance its value  or diminish it?

articles.headline: In Boston, Paper’s Peril Hits a Nerve
articles.snippet: The threat of a shutdown or a sale of The Boston Globe has brought together civic leaders and residents, speaking out about the paper’s role in the region.
articles.abstract: The threat of a shutdown or a sale of The Boston Globe has brought together civic leaders and residents, speaking out about the paper’s role in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  When local bloggers rallied last week in an online forum about how to save the embattled Boston Globe, readers offered loads of sympathetic advice and surprisingly little of the “let ’em rot” attitude that has colored so much debate over the future of newspapers.

articles.headline: In Switch, Magazines Think About Raising Prices
articles.snippet: As advertising falls, publishers are assessing whether they can charge more without losing subscribers.
articles.abstract: As advertising falls, publishers are assessing whether they can charge more without losing subscribers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fifty-eight cents.

articles.headline: ‘Surgical’ Bankruptcy Possible for G.M.
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department is said to be directing G.M. to prepare for a bankruptcy filing by June 1, if necessary.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department is said to be directing G.M. to prepare for a bankruptcy filing by June 1, if necessary.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Treasury Department is directing General Motors to lay the groundwork for a bankruptcy filing by a June 1 deadline, despite G.M.’s public contention that it could still reorganize outside court, people with knowledge of the plans said during the weekend.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Plan to Change Student Lending Sets Up a Fight
articles.snippet: Private lenders are moving against President Obama’s plan to redirect billions in bank profits to needy students.
articles.abstract: Private lenders are moving against President Obama’s plan to redirect billions in bank profits to needy students.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The private student lending industry and its allies in Congress are maneuvering to thwart a plan by President Obama to end a subsidized loan program and redirect billions of dollars in bank profits to scholarships for needy students.
